content.webTitle: Giles Scott: London 2012 heartbreak pushed me to Rio gold glory

fields.headline: Giles Scott: London 2012 heartbreak pushed me to Rio gold glory
fields.bodyText: After eight days of competition in Guanabara Bay, Giles Scott returned to the shore on Tuesday with a union jack wrapped around his back, ready to receive his first Olympic gold medal in the Finn class. It was a fait accompli. By the end of the 10th race on Sunday, Scott had an unassailable lead. The last two days had been “a luxury”, he said – the very happiest of a four-year wait which began when he was overlooked for selection in the same event at London 2012. “I was pretty disappointed not to get to compete in London,” Scott said. “But what came off the back of that was a lot of desire and the drive to right the wrongs I had made, get here and put on a good show in Rio.” Scott’s victory means that Great Britain has now won the Finn at the last five Olympics, a run that started with Iain Percy in Sydney in 2000 and continued with Sir Ben Ainslie’s back-to-back wins at Athens, Beijing and London, the last of them achieved at Scott’s expense. Whatever else we may lack, we’re not short of brooding, bearded, sailors to helm our dinghy yachts. The great Paul Elvstrøm, who competed at eight Olympics, described the Finn as the one class of Olympic sailing where there was a clear difference between the “good” and the “very good”, who “can always leave distance between himself and others”. And Scott has proved he is very good indeed. Stephen Park, the manager of Britain’s sailing team, said Scott, 29, had a “psychological hold” on everyone else. “The others are all racing for second,” he said. “They look at Giles and say: ‘You know what, this guy is just faster than us.’” Park compared him to Lewis Hamilton. “In F1 terms, if you’re in the Red Bull or the Ferrari, you’ve got some good kit, but he’s in the Mercedes, so you just have to hope he makes a mistake.” On the first day of the competition, Scott did. He misjudged the tides and wound up 17th out of 23. “Some people would say it was his first Olympics, so he had a touch of nerves,” said Park. “I’m not actually sure it was that, but just a simple error.” Either way, he thinks it fired Scott up, and he has since finished first in three races, second in two, and third in two more. Scott started sailing when he was six years old. His father John had spent a little time “mucking about in boats” when he was at university, but neither he nor his wife, Ros, had ever taken it seriously. They got their three boys into the sport while the family was living in Canada, just so they had something better to do than hang out at the local mall. Simon Cray, credited by Scott’s father as “the first man to say: ‘This guy can go places’”, coached Scott during his junior years from the age of 10 at Hollowell sailing club, Northampton. “I had the privilege of working with Giles during his junior years,” said Cray. “We knew he had a special talent then, and to see him now reaching gold at the Olympics is just absolutely wonderful.” Asked if he knew the boy he had coached would climb to the top spot, he replied with a simple “yes”, adding: “I knew he would. He was good, had good talent – but above that he had the right sort of mental attitude. I had people who were perhaps at that time slightly better in terms of technical skills, but put them in a race and they didn’t perform. Giles, whatever race you put him in, he came out on top. He was a great talent to work with and I feel extremely privileged to have been part of that.” When he was 18, Scott won the ISAF youth sailing world championships in the Laser, and by 2008 he was training alongside Ainslie in the run-up to the Beijing Games. They didn’t know it then, but three years later they would became fierce rivals for Team GB’s one spot in the Finn at London 2012. Ainslie, who was 35, has since admitted that he felt threatened by Scott. He was so much younger and so much stronger, at a time when Ainslie felt he was beginning to reach his own sell-by date. Scott, who had a young man’s arrogance, was convinced that he was the better sailor. He won the World and the European Championships in 2011, but lost the two crucial Olympic trial races to Ainslie. “Giles was the only person who was beating Ben in the last few months leading up to the Games,” remembers Park. “If he had he been racing at the Games many people would say that he would have won the gold if Ben had not been there.” Ainslie and Scott always insisted they were friends, but you wouldn’t always have known it from the way they behaved out on the water. “Ben was always simmering and occasionally that boiled over,” said Park. “Giles is perfectly assertive and doesn’t let anyone take advantage of him.” Scott once said of his relationship with Ainslie that “there has been the odd shouting match in training. I know why he does it: to assert himself. And I do it to show that I won’t back down.” Park remembers that when Ainslie was picked ahead of him, Scott “was irritated and angry because he thought he was better than Ben at Games time.” In the end Scott spent a lot of the London 2012 regatta on a drinking spree. Scott and Ainslie have now teamed up for the America’s Cup. Ainslie, impressed by just how shrewd and tough Scott was, has made him a key part of the team. “They will be pretty intimidating for most other people,” says Park. “They’re a bit of a dream team. Ben has that outspoken drive and passion. Giles is the computer, still ticking, thinking: ‘This is our next best move, this is our next best move.’” Park wants Scott to come back to compete at both the 2020 and 2024 Olympics. He believes he could well win three Olympic titles. Scott isn’t so sure. “I’ll never create a dynasty like Ainslie did,” he said. “I’m far too old already. “But that doesn’t mean I don’t have my own ambitions in sailing: I’m going off to the America’s Cup and I’d love to be able to bring that back to the UK.” He flies home on Sunday, and will be back to work with Ainslie in just a couple of weeks’ time. But before that he is planning to enjoy a drink or two with his family and friends here in Rio. This time round he will be celebrating – not drowning his sorrows.
